entry.title: Re: Change existing stock items from Non-Batch to Batch M...
entry.content:
Hi,
In SAP, you cannot simply switch a material from non-batch-managed to batch-managed if stock already exists — SAP requires that all stock be cleared first. Without batch management, the only way to track each product individually is to use serial number management instead of batch management

SAP restriction: Once stock exists for a material, you cannot activate batch management in the material master until that stock is consumed or cleared.

Standard process: Clear unrestricted and reserved stock. Change material master to batch managed. Re-post stock with batch numbers (via MIGO).

This is why your scenario (with 300 materials and 8000 finished products) is problematic — clearing stock is not feasible

entry.title: Re: S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition: Factoring Process witho...
entry.content:
Hi @byd ,

I've not used this flow - but did some research for app equivalences etc. and the output is as below. Please review carefully for your scenario to see if it gets you what you need:

Corrected App Mapping:

  • Customer Invoicing: Use "Create Customer Invoice" app (not F-22)
  • Manual Journal Entry: Use "Create Journal Entry" app (replaces FB01)
  • Incoming Payments: Use "Post Incoming Payments" app (replaces F-28)
  • Outgoing Payments: Use "Post Outgoing Payments" app (replaces F-53)
  • Manual Clearing: Use "Clear G/L Account" app (replaces F1579)

Detailed Implementation Steps

Step 1: Invoice Creation (Feb 10)

  • App: Create Customer Invoice
  • Posting:
    • DR: Customer Account ¥1,000,000
    • CR: Revenue Account ¥1,000,000

Step 2: Factoring Transaction (Mar 10)

  • App: Create Journal Entry
  • Posting:
    • DR: Bank Account ¥900,000
    • DR: Factoring Fee Expense ¥100,000
    • CR: Customer Account ¥1,000,000
  • Note: This directly clears the customer AR while recording the factoring fee

Step 3: Customer Payment Receipt (Apr 15)

  • App: Create Journal Entry (not Post Incoming Payments)
  • Posting:
    • DR: Bank Account ¥1,000,000
    • CR: Deposits Payable/Trust Account ¥1,000,000
  • Rationale: Since the AR is already cleared, use journal entry rather than incoming payments

Step 4: Transfer to Factoring Company (Apr 16)

  • App: Post Outgoing Payments or Create Journal Entry
  • Posting:
    • DR: Deposits Payable ¥1,000,000
    • CR: Bank Account ¥1,000,000

Key Considerations

Account Setup Requirements:

  • Create a "Deposits Payable" or "Trust Account" G/L account
  • Set up a "Factoring Fee Expense" G/L account
  • Ensure proper bank account configuration for multiple cash flows

Process Validation:

  • The manual journal entry in Step 2 can indeed clear customer-specific AR directly
  • No additional clearing process needed if postings are structured correctly
  • Consider implementing approval workflows for manual journal entries

Alternative Approach: If direct AR clearing via journal entry faces restrictions, consider:

  1. Use "Post Incoming Payments" in Step 2 with a clearing account
  2. Post the factoring fee separately via journal entry
  3. Use clearing functions to match the transactions

entry.title: Re: Posting a GR without a PO
entry.content: Although movement type 561 can technically bring stock back, it should be avoided because it is intended only for initial stock uploads. For operational scenarios like loaned material returns, please use movement type 501 (GR without PO) in MIGO/MB1C. It is not clear what the issue is when you tried 501 movement type.  Please share screen shot of the issue.  If the material is linked to project stock, movement type 521 is the appropriate alternative.

entry.title: Unable to create HU's after GR posting from custom fiori app in s4 hana public cloud.
entry.content:
Hello Experts,

Need your expertise here.

We are working on S/4HANA Public Cloud (WM-managed storage location).
We have developed a custom SAPUI5 application to perform Goods Receipt for inbound materials. The GR posting is successfully done using the standard API:
• API_MATERIAL_DOCUMENT_SRV
Service: /sap/opu/odata/sap/API_MATERIAL_DOCUMENT_SRV
When GR is posted from the standard SAP Web GUI / Fiori “Post Goods Movement”, the system automatically creates:
1. Warehouse Task (WT)
2. Handling Unit (HU)
However, when the GR is posted using API_MATERIAL_DOCUMENT_SRV, no Warehouse Task or Handling Unit is created automatically.
We require the same system behavior through the API, because warehouse operations depend on HU creation after GR.
⸻
✅ Expected Behavior
• After GR posting via API, system should trigger WM follow-up actions:
✅ Create Handling Unit
✅ Create Warehouse Task
✅ HU should reference the material document
⸻
✅ Actual Behavior
• Material document is successfully created.
• No Warehouse Task is created.
• No Handling Unit is created.
• There is no documented public API that creates HU for a GR in WM-managed locations.
⸻
✅ What we already checked
✔ API_MATERIAL_DOCUMENT_SRV
✔ API_PURCHASEORDER_2_SRV
✔ API_INBOUND_DELIVERY_SRV
✔ API_HANDLING_UNIT (A2X) – not available / not supported in our S/4HANA Public Cloud system
✔ No BAdI or extensibility available for auto-HU creation after GR
✔ No replacement API documented in SAP API Hub for HU creation from GR
⸻
✅ Request
1. Please confirm whether automatic HU + WT creation is supported when GR is posted via API in a WM-managed storage location in S/4HANA Public Cloud.
2. If supported, provide:
• API name
• Service path
• Sample payload
• Any required configuration
3. If not supported, please confirm if this is a product limitation and provide recommended alternative.
⸻
✅ System Details
• S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
• Scope Item: Warehouse Management in Stock Room Management (If applicable)
• Material Document posted via: API_MATERIAL_DOCUMENT_SRV
⸻
✅ Steps to Reproduce
1. Use API_MATERIAL_DOCUMENT_SRV to post GR for PO
2. GR document successfully created
3. Check /SCWM/PRDI or HU Fiori app → no HU, no WT

entry.title: One central learning page is now available for the entire SAP Business One community and friends!
entry.content:
No more searching across platforms, emails, or bookmarks — visit our dedicated SAP Business One page on learning.sap.com for all your training needs:

The training is public and free. Spread the word! 

And don’t forget ‘Mi casa es su casa’ so make our SAP Business One learning page your homepage.

Important: SAP Business One training programs on SAP Learning Hub will be retired on December 15, 2025. From now on, please use the new SAP Business One page at learning.sap.com as your reference.

entry.title: Introducing a new version 1.0.1 of the Pipeline for Cloud Integration packages
entry.content:
A new version 1.0.1 of the Pipeline for Cloud Integration packages has been recently shipped. This is the first increment of the newly split up packages. I hope you remember, with the last update we decided to split up the now deprecated package into 4 packages to better support the setup of multiple pipelines, see New integration packages for the Pipeline for Cloud Integration.

At that point of time we replaced the scripts from the script collection with local scripts and deprecated the script collection since this was part of the deprecated package anyway. Using local scripts in the generic flow gives us more flexibility in setting up multiple pipelines. However, for the scripts in the provided templates we received feedback that customers prefer to have a script collection because scenario-specific flows are built as copy of the templates and if the local scripts need to be updated then this would result into high maintenance effort. So, we decided to provide a new script collection at least for the templates. This script collection is shipped with the templates package and the templates that uses scripts have been updated to use the scripts from the script collection. If you have scenario-specific flows that either use the old script collection or the local scripts, you need to replace them with the new script collection. Sorry for the inconvenience, but you have to update your existing scenario-specific flows that use scripts anyway because for the new script collection we had to define a new ID.

Besides this change, the new version comes with a couple of new features based on customer demand. The new features are as follows:

  • We now support a generic IDoc outbound flow to standardize and ease the configuration of IDoc outbound scenarios.
  • We now support a generic XI outbound flow to standardize and ease the configuration of XI outbound scenarios.
  • We have improved the support for sender and receiver parties.
  • We have improved the support for receiver-specific queues and the definition of the queue for receiver-specific outbound processing.
  • In a sender wildcard scenario, we now support inbound conversion per sender.
  • Non-XML payloads are encoded before storing in an exchange property to avoid that the payload gets corrupted when reading from the exchange property again.
  • For some scenarios, you have the option to run scenarios in the pipeline without the need of the Partner Directory.

If you like to leverage the new features, you need to update all 4 packages. If you already use the pipeline, your packages are labeled with update available, also for those packages that you created as copy with suffix.

Generic IDoc outbound flow

For scenarios in which Cloud Integration connects to receiver systems exchanging IDoc messages, you can use the generic outbound integration flow Pipeline v2 Generic Step08 - Outbound Processing for IDoc from the integration package Cloud Integration Pipeline - Generic Outbound.

You can setup the generic IDoc outbound either using one single generic IDoc outbound integration flow across all your receiving systems or using one generic IDoc outbound integration flow for each receiving system. In any case, the generic IDoc outbound integration flow allows you to setup your IDoc outbound scenarios in a common way including built-in support for guaranteed delivery and error handling.

Because we use a generic flow across multiple scenarios, the IDoc receiver adapter parameters and the IDoc control headers are dynamically set during runtime. Here, the following configuration options are supported:

  • Configuring externalized parameters of the generic IDoc outbound integration flow.
  • Maintaining the parameters in the Partner Directory.
  • Creating message headers in the scenario-specific outbound processing flow.
  • Defining the IDoc control header in the message body in the scenario-specific outbound processing flow.

For more details about the configuration options, refer to the IDoc Receiver Adapter chapter in the help documentation.

Generic XI outbound flow

For scenarios in which Cloud Integration connects to receiver systems using the XI message protocol, you can use the generic outbound integration flow Pipeline v2 Generic Step08 - Outbound Processing for XI from the integration package Cloud Integration Pipeline - Generic Outbound. Here, the generic XI outbound flow supports both asynchronous as well as synchronous communication.

Like for the generic IDoc outbound, you can setup the generic XI outbound either using one single generic XI outbound integration flow across all your receiving systems or using one generic XI outbound integration flow for each receiving system.

The XI receiver adapter parameters and the XI header attributes are dynamically set during runtime. The following configuration options are supported:

  • Configuring externalized parameters of the generic XI outbound integration flow.
  • Maintaining Partner Directory parameters.
  • Maintaining message headers in the scenario-specific outbound processing flow.

For more details about the configuration options, refer to the XI Receiver Adapter in the help documentation.

Sender and receiver parties

Scenarios with sender and receiver parties are better supported now. We decided to go for a simplified approach by concatenating the party name if any with the sender or receiver component name. The headers SAP_Sender and SAP_Receiver show the concatenated names in the message monitor. In addition to this, we create new headers SAP_SenderParty and SAP_ReceiverParty which can be used in the subsequent flows, especially this is needed for the XI outbound.

If you have a sender party, in the Partner Directory maintain the alternative partner of the configuration scenario as follows: define the agency as a combination of the sender party and the sender component name separated by a dot.

If you have a receiver party, define the receiver service name within the XSLT that you run to determine the receiver and the receiver interface as combination of the receiver party and the receiver component name separated by a dot.

When running the scenario, in the message processing log, the sender and receiver information is displayed as follows:

  • The Sender and the Receiver in the Properties section show the concatenated party/component names.
  • Custom header properties SenderParty and ReceiverParty are added showing the party names.
  • Custom header properties SenderSystem and ReceiverSystem are added showing the component names, here the actual business system names depending on the landscape stage in case that you use the landscape staging feature.
  • If you use the landscape staging feature, and your actual business system differ from the alias names used within the pipeline, the alias names SenderAlias and ReceiverAlias are added as custom header properties.

Receiver-specific queues

By default, each scenario uses the same set of generic JMS queues. For receivers for which you want to control the outbound delivery, you can define receiver-specific JMS queues. So far, this was done for a particular receiver. Now, you can define a dedicated queue for a particular receiver and for  a particular scenario. For latter, you can define different receiver-specific queues for the same receiver depending on your particular configuration scenario. The scenario-specific setting overrides the global setting.

If you like to use a receiver-specific JMS outbound queue across all your scenarios, create a partner in the Partner Directory with the partner ID equaling the business system name and a string parameter with ID ReceiverSpecificQueue. As value, enter the receiver-specific queue name.

If you like to define a receiver-specific JMS outbound queue for a particular configuration scenario only, define a corresponding string parameter for the partner ID representing your configuration scenario. In this case, the string parameter ID is a combination of the constant identifier ReceiverSpecificQueue and the business system name separated with an underscore "_". As value, enter the scenario/receiver-specific queue name.

For each receiver-specific queue, you need to copy the generic outbound processing flow and configure the JMS queue name accordingly. Don't directly copy, instead copy the integration package Cloud Integration Pipeline - Generic Outbound from the Discover Artifacts area of your tenant. This way, the copied flow is still receiving the regular updates if any. As you can see in the screenshot below, we have improved the JMS queue maintenance to be more flexible in defining receiver-specific queues. Besides the prefix you can now also define a suffix. By default, the suffix is empty. The JMS queue name is then concatenated using the prefix, the constant Q04 and the suffix.

And here we go. If you run the scenario, the receivers Receiver_11 and Receiver_12 use the queue defined in the scenario whereas receiver Receiver_13 uses the one defined in the business system.

Inbound conversion

To determine whether your specific scenario needs an inbound conversion, you create a string parameter holding the ProcessDirect endpoint of your scenario-specific inbound conversion flow. So far, you could only define one inbound conversion per scenario. In a sender wildcard scenario, i.e., a scenario in which the same configuration applies to different sender systems, you may have the requirement to define different inbound conversions depending on the sender system. This is supported now.

If you need inbound conversion and you only have one sender for your configuration scenario, create one scenario-specific inbound conversion flow and configure the string parameter InboundConversionEndpoint in the Partner Directory pointing to the ProcessDirect endpoint of the scenario-specific integration flow.

In case of sender wildcard scenarios, you have two options. If your inbound conversion is the same for each sender system, you only need to create one single scenario-specific inbound conversion flow and hence only have to maintain one configuration parameter InboundConversionEndpoint. If the inbound conversion differs depending on the sender systems, you need to create scenario-specific inbound conversion flows for each sender system and hence have the option to maintain a configuration parameter for each sender system as combination of the constant term InboundConversionEndpoint and the sender system name separated by underscore "_". The system-specific parameter overrules the scenario-specific parameter.

When running the scenario, you can see that the business system BS_DD2_Q with system alias BS_DD2 uses the sender-specific inbound conversion.

Extension for scenario configuration

If you prefer not to use the Partner Directory, you have the option to configure most of the parameters defining your configuration scenario as custom parameters in your scenario-specific inbound processing flows. The custom parameters are passed to the generic pipeline flows and if present the Partner Directory is not called.

For more details about the alternative scenario configuration, see Run Pipeline for Cloud Integration without the Partner Directory.

entry.title: Run Pipeline for Cloud Integration without the Partner Directory
entry.content:
With the new version 1.0.1 of the Pipeline for Cloud Integration packages, we have added the possibility to configure your configuration scenario without the need of the Partner Directory. If you prefer not to use the Partner Directory, you have the option to configure most of the parameters defining your configuration scenario as custom headers in your scenario-specific inbound processing flows. The custom headers are passed to the generic pipeline flows and if present the Partner Directory is not called.

As you may know, the Pipeline for Cloud Integration is not yet supported on Edge Integration Cell due to the missing support for the Partner Directory on Edge Integration Cell. We do have the support for the Partner Directory on Edge Integration Cell in our roadmap, see Support for the partner directory, but as long as it is not supported you may try out the Pipeline on Edge Integration Cell already today. And once this is shipped, you can switch to the Partner Directory and then leverage the full feature scope of the Pipeline.

With this extension, not all scenarios and features are supported. For instance, we do not support XI and IDoc inbound scenarios because here we do not have an option to define the custom headers in the inbound. Furthermore, we do not support tenant staging and receiver specific outbound queues because here a call to the Partner Directory would be needed.

Also, for content-based-router and recipient list patterns, we can't read an XSLT from the Partner Directory which is the standard approach to carry out the XPath conditions to determine receivers and interfaces. Instead you need to apply custom receiver and interface determination, i.e., calling a custom integration flow where you determine the receivers and interfaces. For this you have different options like running a message mapping or an XSLT, and lately we have shipped options using groovy scripts, see New templates for the Pipeline for Cloud Integration: enhancing the custom receiver determination.

Besides those templates, we also provide a more generic template Pipeline v2 Template Step04 - Custom Receiver Determination in the templates package that you can copy and then upload any message mapping or XSLT. An option would be using the Partner Directory Accelerator Tool for Pipeline Concept to create the XSLT by maintaining the XPath conditions in the accelerator tool. This way, the switch to the Partner Directory once supported would be easier because you can then simply reuse the XSLT.

As mentioned above, for bypassing the Partner Directory you need to define custom headers in the scenario-specific inbound flow. Besides other headers, headers starting with customX are in the allowed list of the generic flows and hence can be passed to the generic flows.

For compatibility reasons, it's mandatory to create the header partnerID. If the header exists, the generic pipeline won't try to map the sender component name and the sender interface name to a partner ID in the Partner Directory. Otherwise, your message will fail.

Let's configure and deploy two different scenarios on Edge Integration Cell, one Content-Based-Router and one Point-to-Point scenario. We will only use the integrated messaging runtime, so we just have to deploy the two generic flows Pipeline v2 Generic Step02 - Integrated Messaging Runtime Async and Pipeline v2 Generic Step06 - Outbound Processing on Edge Integration Cell.

 

Content-Based-Router

To run a Content-Based-Router scenario on Edge Integration Cell, we need to create an integration flow which is called to determine the receivers and interfaces. As proposed above, we created the integration flow as copy of the generic custom receiver determination template and used the XSLT from the Partner Directory, i.e., we downloaded the XSLT from the Partner Directory, and imported it as reference to the integration flow.

Next, we need to configure the configuration scenario in the scenario-specific inbound flow.

In a content modifier step, the following mandatory message headers need to be created:

  • partnerID with value equals the configuration scenario name.
  • customXRDEndpoint with value equals the ProcessDirect endpoint of the custom receivers and interfaces integration flow, see above.
 
Because this scenario needs an inbound conversion to convert the incoming message from JSON to XML, we have to create an inbound conversion integration flow, and hence have to create the header customXInboundConversionEndpoint with value equals the ProcessDirect endpoint of the integration flow performing the inbound conversion.

In addition, we created the following optional headers:

  • maxJMSRetries to define a scenario-specific maximum number of retries overriding the default value which is 5. In our case we changed the value to 1.
  • customXPreEnabled specifying the pipeline steps for which we like to call a custom pre-processing flow, in our case for both generic pipeline steps (02 stands for the integrated messaging runtime, and 06 stands for the generic outbound processing). See New feature for the Pipeline for Cloud Integration: custom preprocessing exit.
  • customXPreEndpoint with value equals the ProcessDirect endpoint of the custom pre-processing flow.

Once, all integration flows have been deployed on the Edge Integration Cell runtime, we can run the scenario. As you can see in the screenshot below, the custom receiver determination flow has been called. Furthermore, for both pipeline steps the custom preprocessing flow has been called.

 

Point-to-Point

Now, let's setup an asynchronous Point-to-Point (P2P) scenario where most of the pipeline is actually bypassed. For this, we need to create a scenario-specific inbound flow and a scenario-specific outbound flow. The scenario-specific inbound flow directly calls the generic outbound processing flow so that the message is persisted in the JMS queue to ensure restart and Exactly Once delivery. The generic outbound processing flow then delivers the message to the scenario-specific outbound flow.

In the scenario-specific inbound flow, we create the following mandatory headers:

  • partnerID with value equals the configuration scenario name.
  • SAP_OutboundProcessingEndpoint with value equals the ProcessDirect endpoint of the scenario-specific outbound flow. This header is passed to the generic outbound processing flow which then sends the message to the corresponding scenario-specific outbound flow.

In addition, we created the following optional headers:

  • SAP_Receiver holding the name of the receiver system. This can be added to show up in the message monitor.
  • maxJMSRetries to define a scenario-specific maximum number of retries overriding the default value.
  • customXPreEnabled specifying the pipeline steps for which we like to call a custom pre-processing flow. For P2P, we only use the generic outbound processing, i.e., pipeline step number 06.
  • customXPreEndpoint with value equals the ProcessDirect endpoint of the custom pre-processing flow.

Once, all integration flows have been deployed on Edge Integration Cell, we can run the scenario.

For more details, see Custom Scenario Configuration.

entry.title: Custom field not accessible in /SCWM/WAREHOUSE_REQUEST_HDR business context Public Cloud
entry.content:
Hi Experts,

When creating a custom field using the Custom Fields app for the business context /SCWM/WAREHOUSE_REQUEST_HDR, the generated artifacts are of type CDS View only.

Although the field appears correctly in the delivery order UI and can be marked as “modifiable”, it is not accessible from the Customer Data Browser (transaction /N/SCWM/CBrowser) nor from ABAP code when implementing a warehouse-related BAdI as /SCWM/EX4_CORE_RMS_DETERMINE.

The generated CDS views for /SCWM/WAREHOUSE_REQUEST_HDR business context are plain CDS View types, not Custom Entity, and appear not to be extended into the runtime structures used by EWM warehouse request BAdIs.

Is this a restriction of the business context /SCWM/WAREHOUSE_REQUEST_HDR, or is there an enhancement point or configuration required to make the custom field accessible at runtime (e.g., via BAdI or CDS extension)?

Thanks

entry.title: Pricing procedure in Purchase Contracts
entry.content:
Dear Experts,

I would like to understand how the pricing procedure works in Purchase Contracts. As per my understanding, it seems to be controlled through condition supplementary, please correct me if I’m wrong.

When I try to maintain header conditions, they are not reflecting at the item level in the Purchase Contract. I would like to know if this behavior is due to condition supplementation, and whether there is an option to define or control the actual pricing procedure for Contracts.

Best regards,

Dinesh U

entry.title: Re: Is there any spreadsheet or help site that maps scope...
entry.content:
Dear @davi3,

There isn’t a built-in “scope item classic module (SD/MM/FI…)” view in the Test Automation Tool (TAT). TAT can filter by Application Area or by Scope Item ID, but not by “OTC/L2C, SD, etc.” directly.

More details below on SAP Community:

https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-sap/sap-s-4hana-cloud-test-automation-tool-in-sap-s-4hana-cloud-public-edition/ba-p/13774985

BUT you can find by „How to find scope items on SAP Signavio Process Navigator” below from SAP Note:

https://me.sap.com/notes/0003382435

and from the Excel file, for example in the Scope Item ID column filter by BD9, you can now see which business area and activity area has been assigned.

You can download the file from the SAP For Me portal as below: (Process steps, business roles and apps)

 

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: Re: Bank Account Mandatory without Removing Delete Permis...
entry.content: Hi Gopinath - Could you please help with requested queries?

entry.title: Certificações SAP: mudança para formato prático e open-book
entry.content:
💼Certificação SAP: novo formato prático em implementação

A SAP está transformando o formato das certificações para refletir melhor a forma como trabalhamos atualmente.

O que muda: Ao invés de questões teóricas de múltipla escolha, o novo formato inclui:

 

  • Tarefas práticas em sistemas SAP reais
  • Cenários simulados com avatares de IA representando situações de clientes
  • Acesso a recursos como SAP Help, Community e Joule durante o exame

 

A proposta é alinhar a certificação com o ambiente de trabalho real: colaborativo, conectado e com IA integrada.

Mais informações: https://community.sap.com/t5/sap-learning-blog-posts/reimagining-certification-for-the-way-we-work-today/ba-p/14261141

entry.title: SAP Business Network for Logistics - Dock Appointment Scheduling: Announcing Recurring Block Times
entry.content:
Version

VersionDateChanges
1.014.11.2025Initial Version - Daily Recurrence for Test Tenants

 

Introduction

Efficient dock scheduling is critical for smooth logistics operations. SAP Business Network for Logistics (BN4L) Dock Appointment Scheduling is constantly evolving to meet the needs of modern supply chains. Today, we’re excited to announce the new Recurring Block Times feature which will be first time available with the 2511 (Nov 15th, 2025) release for Test Tenants.


Feature Availability

The Recurring Block Times feature will be available for Test Tenants with the upcoming 2511 release of SAP Business Network for Logistics Dock Appointment Scheduling.

Outlook:

  • Release Schedule and Dates
  • What's New in SAP Business Network Freight Collaboration
  • What's New in the Test Tenants of SAP Business Network Freight Collaboration
  • Release 2512/2601 Test Tenants:  
    • Extend recurring block times for weekly and monthly recurrences
    • Further Improvements on the existing functionality
  • Release 2602 Production Tenants:
    • Planned feature availably for productive tenants


What Are Recurring Block Times?

Recurring Block Times allow logistics managers to automatically block specific time slots on a recurring basis—such as every Monday morning or the first Friday of each month. This feature is ideal for:

  • Regular maintenance windows
  • Reserved periods for priority shipments
  • Staff meetings or training sessions
  • Public holidays or company events
  • etc.


New Feature “Recurring Block Time”

  • Creation of blocker series (2511 Daily Recurrence) in Manage Entities App for a Loading Point
  • Block specific capacity of a loading point or block the maximum capacity including overbooking across validity periods. Please see SAP Business Network for Logistics - Dock Appointment Scheduling: Maximum Capacity Blocker
  • Capacity check if the slot capacity exceeds the capacity of the validity period defined for the loading point
  • Release single Blocks from the series from Manage Dock Appointment App


Key Benefits

  • Automated Planning: Set up recurring blocks once and let the system manage future reservations.
  • Reduced Scheduling Conflicts: Prevent accidental bookings during blocked periods.
  • Improved Resource Allocation: Ensure resources are available when needed most.
  • Flexible Adjustments: Easily modify or remove recurring blocks as business needs change.


How to Use Recurring Block Times

  1. Access the Manage Entities App:
    Open the Manage Entities app in BN4L Dock Appointment Scheduling.
  2. Define Recurring Block Times:
    Select your loading point and choose the “Recurring Block Times” option. Specify the recurrence pattern (daily, weekly, monthly), start/end times, and a description.
  3. Save and Apply:
    Once saved, these blocks will automatically appear in your dock appointment schedule, preventing bookings during the specified periods.
  4. Monitor and Adjust:
    Review blocked times in your scheduling overview and make adjustments as needed.

 

Sneak Preview 2511

Overview Video: Daily Recurring Block Series 2511

 

Creating a Recurring Block Series

Block Creation Options

  • Switching Between Block Types:
    You can choose to create either a Single Block or a Recurring Block. Select the desired option before proceeding with block configuration.

Configuring a Recurring Block Series

  1. Start and End Date/Time:
    Specify the start and end date and time for the recurring block series.
  2. Recurrence Interval:
    Define how often the block should repeat (e.g., every second day, weekly, monthly).
  3. Recurrence End Date:
    Set the end date for the recurring block series.

Notes on Recurring Blocks

  • If you select All Day Event, the start and end time fields will be disabled, and the entire day will be blocked.
  • For All Day Event blocks, ensure that the recurrence interval is not shorter than the duration of the block to prevent overlapping blocks.
  • All other settings are consistent for both Single and Recurring Block creation.

Capacity Settings

  • If you select Max. Capacity, the capacity input will be disabled, and the entire capacity for the loading point will be blocked.

Shipper View in Manage Dock Appointment: Calendar view

Shipper View in Manage Dock Appointment: Release a Single Block from the Series

Single blocks can be released using the Manage Dock Appointment App. Releasing a single block will free up the previously blocked capacity, making it available for new appointment bookings.

Note:
Releasing a single block does not impact any recurring block series that have been created for the loading point. Only the specific block is released, and the recurring series remains unchanged.

  • For shippers: Capacity becomes available for booking via the Manage Dock Appointment App.
  • For carriers: Capacity can be booked through the Self-Book Dock Appointments interface.

Block Creation - Capacity Check

When creating a Single or Recurring Block, the system automatically checks if sufficient appointment capacity is available for the selected date and time slot.

  • If there are existing blocks or booked appointments that overlap with the requested time, the system will prevent the creation of a new block if not enough remaining capacity is available that can be consumed by the new block.

Note:
If there is no available appointment capacity for the desired time slot, you must either release existing blocks or reschedule already booked appointments to free up capacity before creating a new block.

 

Further Information 

  • Release Schedule and Dates
  • What's New in SAP Business Network Freight Collaboration
  • What's New in the Test Tenants of SAP Business Network Freight Collaboration
  • Shipper Apps and APIs - Dock Appointment Scheduling
  • Carrier Apps and APIs - Self-Book Dock Appointments
  • Shipper APIs (SOAP APIs) - Dock Appointment Scheduling
  • Business Accelerator Hub - SAP Business Network Freight Collaboration (SOAP API)

entry.title: Re: How to batch upload G/L accounts in S/4 Public Cloud...
entry.content:
Hi @Grace_Li1,

Thanks very much for your question. There are a couple of things going on here.

First, the “Not Used” flag is obsolete within the Renumber G/L Accounts configuration activity. You should instead use the Implementation Status feature to mark accounts as not used.

As far as batching, there is no inbuilt batching mechanism. If you want to batch your G/L account uploads, then just go ahead and separate them into discrete files and upload the mapping data and the descriptions for each self-made batch as normal. You can batch them by delivered ID, account type, account group, or whatever other way makes the most sense for you. Just be sure to also update the mapping descriptions as well.

Finally, to maintain the accounts that weren’t automatically updated, you should use the Manage G/L Accounts Master Data app. This app will make it substantially easier to handle this.

Thank you!

entry.title: SAP S/4 Public cloud - Service - Service order generated by maintenance plan without service team
entry.content:
Dear experts, 

I am implementing SAP S/4HANA public cloud service module for a customer. The service team is activated in service document via CBC.

When I execute Recurring service process (4X5), there is the step to plan the maintenance plan, the result is one or x service order are created. I have an issue : the service error contains issues : service team field is blank. I understand because in public cloud neither in the service contract, nor in service order template.  In the help sap documentation, it's written : Service organizational data is copied from service contract to a generated service order. (https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/adbae5bcd5994f159bf2847a11397b61/5c28583fd4554a3cb9261aecb7ea4e24.html?locale=en-US)

As the field Service Team is not in the service contract, I don't understand how the copy is possible.

Can you explain me how is it possible for maintenance plan to generate service order without this such error ? This data is really important to dispatch the job, if it's blank, someone has to fulfill this information everytime without any value, it's time consumming. Can SAP add the service team field in the contract object ???

Thanks a lot

entry.title: Re: How to Delete Unwanted Standard Pre-Delivered Materia...

Hello,

Deletion of material groups delivered as part of Standard Best Practice pre-delivered content is currently not supported.

This information is available in the 4KL sheet, in Configuration Activity.xlsm (SAP Customer) file, available for download at Request Expert Configuration (3-system landscape) - SAP For Me.

Regards,
SAP Support.

entry.title: Re: patch/create Account Assignment M for a existing Purc...
entry.content:
Hello @Phil_P 

Thank you for your question.

To summarise, account assignment handling in public cloud for purchase order through OData follows a two-step logic because of how the manage transactional consistency works within the clean-core framework.

You are correct that the system treats the Item-level “AccountAssignmentCategory” as an update to the item entity. The account assignment line itself as a create (POST) under the nested entity set _PurOrdAccountAssignment.

However, OData service for purchase Orders does not support performing both actions in a single payload or PATCH call. You are required to perform these operations sequentially. First you need to update the item category, then create the account assignment line.

Have a look at the following references for further details.

APIs in Sourcing and Procurement, Operations for Purchase Order, Display Purchasing Documents by Account Assignment, Account assignment in purchasing document

 

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: サプライヤ請求書の転記制御方法
entry.content:
Dear @Tyamada,

My recommendation below: If I understood your case incorrectly please let me know and describe in English.

  • Configure the flexible workflow for “Parked Invoice as Complete” in Manage Workflows for Supplier Invoices. The creator uses Save as Completed, which triggers approval in My Inbox.

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/0e602d466b99490187fcbb30d1dc897c/9bd9a6b4124446a5b31ddfecbff07508.html

 

  • Authorizations / apps (role separation)
  • Role A – Creator: grant access to Park Supplier Invoices (so they can hold/park)

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/0e602d466b99490187fcbb30d1dc897c/2527430934784953a5659106578ca695.html

 

  • Role B – Approver/Poster: grant My Inbox for approvals and allow posting after approval
  • Hard safeguard (Public Cloud BadI)
    Because the Post button can bypass workflow, implement the BadI MRM_CHECK_INVOICE_CLOUD (via Custom Logic app) to block posting until the invoice is approved.

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3673139

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3496626

 

BadI logic (idea):
If Action = Post and the invoice is not yet approved / still In Approval, raise an error (for example: „Posting not allowed, in approval status”.

 

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: Re: Business rule for Variable Pay and/or Rewards&Recognition that are using data from custom MD
entry.content: Tatiana, For the Var Pay question, MDF tables do not work in that manner. The Rows are read and that row is determined to be eligible or ineligible. We have for other clients used a separate VP template where we calculate the number of days in each assignment and then total the number of days at the entry level. We usually see this condition for leaves, not one off days where the employee is sick or on vacation. The situation would indicate days eligible and days on leave. This would require an assignment record for the time that is off. If seems like you may not have that data. From there you can use a custom column to calculate if a person is ineligible or eligible base on the number of days and load a TRUE/FALSE column into the MDF and thn reference that column in your eligibility rule. An alternative would be to calculate outside the system and load a TRUE/FALSE value into the MDF.

entry.title: Story report convert a date and time column to only display the date
entry.content:
Searching the list of functions https://help.sap.com/docs/successfactors-platform/story-reports/formula-functions-in-calculated-columns-for-sap-analytics-cloud-stories?q=todate I haven't found a way to convert a column that displays a datetime to only display a date.

I tried TODATE function (https://me.sap.com/notes/3139734/E) but its confusing some documentation says it requires a string and then another parameter. Others say if it's a datemine as the first parameter no second parameter is needed. 

for example this is the value of the Performance form - Form start date Jul 21, 2025 7:59:59 PM

When I try to use TODATE in a calculated column with the performance form start date I just get an error if I use one parameter and if I try two parameters it gives an error that it is not a string.

entry.title: How to Unassign Freight Unit (FU) from Freight Order (FO) using BOPF action in ABAP (SCMTMS/TOR)?
entry.content:
Hello SAP Community,

I am working on an ABAP development requirement within SAP Transportation Management (TM) and need to programmatically unassign a Freight Unit (FU) from a Freight Order (FO).

In an other development method DO_ACTION of class /bobf/if_tra_service_manager was used to assign to freight unit to freight order with the following code:

 

DATA: lo_srv_mgr    TYPE REF TO /bobf/if_tra_service_manager.

*-- Initialize service manager for TOR
  lo_srv_mgr = /bobf/cl_tra_serv_mgr_factory=>get_service_manager( /scmtms/if_tor_c=>sc_bo_key ).

  TRY.
      CALL METHOD lo_srv_mgr->do_action
        EXPORTING
          iv_act_key    = /scmtms/if_tor_c=>sc_action-root-add_fu_by_fuid   
          it_key        = VALUE #( ( key = <la_un>-db_key_odn ) )     "GUID FREIGHT ORDER
*         it_key        = lt_n_fo_key
          is_parameters = NEW /scmtms/s_tor_a_add_elements( string = lv_fu_str )  " FREIGHT UNI
*         is_parameters = lr_s_parameters
        IMPORTING
          eo_message    = lo_message
          et_failed_key = DATA(lt_fail).
    CATCH /bobf/cx_frw_contrct_violation.
  ENDTRY.

Now I was thinking about doing something similar, but I can't find the right action key among costants in /scmtms/if_tor_c=>sc_action .

Any suggestions?
Thanks in advance

entry.title: Re: Business rule for Variable Pay and/or Rewards&Recognition that are using data from custom MD
entry.content: For the RnR issue, You should again have a field that is a TRUE/FALSE field for eligibility. This field should be defaulted to false and have a business rule update the field when the disciplinary action field is updated. You might want to have a rule that runs regularly to update the MDF so the eligibility is updated on a regular basis.

entry.title: Re: Standard bank file format "JP_ZENGINKYO" does not out...
entry.content:
Good day @khanhlynx99 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at the following references for further details.

Payment Medium Format, Creating Custom Payment Medium Formats, Creating Custom Payment Medium Formats, Customizing for Payments

To summarise, in public cloud, when you use or copy a standard payment medium format (such as JP_ZENGINKYO) in the Manage Payment Medium Formats app, it is common to observe that certain standard mapping sources (e.g., FPAYHX-REFxx) appear empty in your custom format even though data exists in the payment run.

The reason is because of how the standard extraction logic for the FPAYHX (Header) and FPAYP (item) structures is encapsulated in SAP’s internal class CL_PYMTM_FORMAT_JP_ZENGINKYO, which cannot be modified or enhanced in the public cloud.

When you copy the standard format, that link to the SAP internal extraction routine is not inherited, and therefore, the system does not populate the FPAYHX reference fields unless the mapping source explicitly refers to a supported structure or field populated by your custom logic.

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Value is shown in one line of the mapping but not in the next lines
entry.content:
Hello,

entry.title: Re: why we have a gap between production order in capacit...
entry.content:
Hello @nicolasduches 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at the following references for further details.

Capacity Scheduling Table, App Extensibility: Capacity Scheduling Table, Lean Manufacturing Planning and Control, How to Realign Schedules

To summarise, the capacity scheduling table app in public cloud, uses finite scheduling logic which is based on capacity intervals, operation duration and scheduling control parameters. When you use “Realign Schedules” à Find slot, the system does not simply compress all operations back-to-back. Instead, it performs a rescheduling simulation that respects the available capacity intervals, rounding logic and any planning fences. That is why you see gaps between production orders even when the work center is set to 24 hours available, you use single-operation production orders, and you have minimal setup or teardown times.

You can avoid this by:

  • Using Reschedule or Dispatch instead of Find Slot for continuous flow.
  • Review your capacity interval setup to ensure truly continuous 00:00-24:00 availability

 

The conclusion is, the behaviour you experienced is standard and was designed to ensure compliance with the clean-core approach in public cloud.

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Cloud-Native with ABAP Cloud – The Transactional Outbox Pattern
entry.content:
Cloud-Native with ABAP Cloud – The Transactional Outbox Pattern

Cheers ABAP folks!

In modern, distributed system landscapes, ensuring data consistency between a database and a message broker is a common challenge – especially when it comes to the integration of S/4HANA Cloud with Side-by-Side extensions built on the SAP Business Technology Platform (e.g. SAP BTP ABAP Environment, aka. Steampunk) or any other microservice-based architecture.

How do you guarantee that a database update (“Order created”) and a corresponding message (like "Request a shipping of the order") are never out of sync? The answer lies in the Transactional Outbox Pattern. This elegant solution ensures that these two critical operations are treated as a single, atomic unit, which is vital for maintaining data integrity and building robust, event-driven architectures atop SAP's core business processes.

 

The Logical Unit of Work

The Logical Unit of Work (LUW) in ABAP represents a series of database operations that are treated as a single, indivisible transaction. All changes made within an LUW, whether updates, insertions, or deletions, must either be committed to the database successfully or rolled back entirely if an error occurs, ensuring transactional consistency. This "all or nothing" principle is managed by the ABAP transaction service, typically involving database commits to finalize the changes. In standard ABAP programming, a database LUW ends when a program executes a COMMIT WORK or ROLLBACK WORK statement, or when a dialog transaction concludes. However, transactional consistency can only be ensured within the same database system. There are plenty of alternatives, when it comes to cloud-native architecture and micro service design. However, a well-established approach is to apply the paradigm of eventual consistency.

 

Eventual Consistency

Eventual consistency is a relaxed consistency model in distributed systems where updates are not instantly propagated, meaning different replicas might temporarily show conflicting data. However, given enough time and the assumption that no further updates occur, the system guarantees that all data will reach a consistent state (soon).

 

The Transactional Outbox Pattern

The transactional outbox pattern directly supports eventual consistency by decoupling the primary data write from the external message emission. It ensures the message has been reliably persisted within the same database transaction as the data change, guaranteeing that the required event will only be sent and consumed by other services, if the main transaction succeeded. Due to the defer of the message emission the micro service is much more robust against spontaneous outages.

Figure 1: Unstable microservice design. Depending on the execution sequence, the transactional data or the status reflected to the remote system might be inconsistent, if the microservice is affected by an outage in between.

Figure 2: More robust microservice design. The message is only emitted, if the transactional data and the outbox, which acts as trigger for the publisher, was successfully committed.

 

Implementing a Transactional Outbox in ABAP Cloud

In ABAP Cloud there is the background processing framework (bgPF) available, which can seamlessly be integrated in the transactional processing of an ABAP application built with the RESTful Application Programming model (RAP).

The clue: Instead of directly emitting outbound messages in the save sequence of your transaction, a handler can be registered, which is executed asynchronously in the background, once the RAP framework successfully complemented the database commit. This custom handler grants additional flexibility on top of the transactional outbox pattern, allowing the ABAP application to control how a certain message should be handled (emitted to an external system, processed internally, etc.).

Figure 3: Implementation of the "Transactional Outbox Pattern" in ABAP Cloud.

This setup involves only two components, everything else is handled by the RAP runtime out-of-the-box:

  • The definition of a bgPF handler, which implements the actual message (e.g. external system call) emission. The handler needs to implement the interface IF_BGMC_OP_SINGLE.
class zcl_rap_bgpf_request_shipping definition
  public
  final
  create private.
  public section.

    class-methods create_instance
      importing
        is_order           type zr_order000
      returning
        value(ro_instance) type ref to if_bgmc_op_single.

    interfaces if_bgmc_op_single.

  protected section.
  private section.

    methods constructor
      importing
        is_order type zr_order000.
    data ms_order type zr_order000.

endclass.
class zcl_rap_bgpf_request_shipping implementation.

  method if_bgmc_op_single~execute.
    "implement outbound call or system local processing
    modify entity zr_shippingrequest
      create
        set fields auto fill cid
          with value #(
            ( %data = value #(
              OrderReference = ms_order-uuid
              ShippingStatus = 'Ordered' )
            )
          )
   mapped data(mapped)
   failed data(failed)
   reported data(reported).
  endmethod.

  method create_instance.
    return new zcl_rap_bgpf_request_shipping( is_order ).
  endmethod.

  method constructor.
    ms_order = is_order.
  endmethod.

endclass.
​
  • The registration of the handler within the save sequence of the RAP business object.
method save_modified.
  "...
  data(lo_factory) = cl_bgmc_process_factory=>get_default( ).
  data(lo_process) = lo_factory->create( ).
  lo_process->set_name( 'Request shipping' )->set_operation(
    zcl_rap_bgpf_request_shipping=>create_instance(
      is_order = corresponding #( <ls_order> )
    )
  ).
  lo_process->save_for_execution( ).
  "...
endmethod.
​

By that, the RAP runtime ensures that the persisted order data is always in sync with the status reflected to the dependent application. If the main process is affected by an outage, the transactional data, as well as the registration for the message emission will be rolled-back. By that, the actual message will never be emitted.

 

Process Monitoring

The background processing framework (bgPF) in ABAP Cloud is technically based on bgRFC processes, which can be monitored via the Fiori app “Monitor bgRFC Queues”. The app displays scheduled, running and aborted processes and provides manual restart capabilities. Important to know: bgPF is one of multiple inbound destinations for bgRFC queues. A queue consists again out of multiple processing units – one of those is our registered handler.

Figure 4: Aborted bgPF process (simulated via assert violations) and its restart capabilities.

 

Additional Information

Check out some more details on the bgPF in general:
https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/introducing-the-background-processing-framework/ba-p/13579056

Official documentation:
https://help.sap.com/docs/abap-cloud/abap-concepts/background-processing-framework

Complete example in GitHub:
https://github.com/SAP-samples/abap-platform-rap-transactional-outbox-with-bgpf

 

Stay tuned for further cloud native design patterns in ABAP Cloud!

Cheerio ABAP Folks!

entry.title: Re: SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud: Disassembly Production Order
entry.content:
Good day @FKai 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at the following references for further details.

https://help.sap.com/doc/b870b6ebcd2e4b5890f16f4b06827064/2020.000/en-US/WN_OP2020_EN.pdf

SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Public Edition for Process Manufacturing (Last Content Update 11/2024)

Manufacturing in SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Public Edition 2302

To summarise, in public cloud, there is no separate Disassembly order type delivered as standard but you can achieve the functionality by using a Production Order with a reverse BOM. This is done through the Disassembly functionality in Production Orders. It uses the same order processing apps and logic as a normal make-to-stock production but with reversed material flows.

If your process requires separate monitoring or analytics, you can copy the standard production order type and rename it for disassembly tracking.

 

Here are further information that are of good guidance.

Make-to-Stock Production - Discrete Manufacturing (BJ5)

Process Navigator - SAP for Me

Make-to-Order Production - Finished Goods Sales and Final Assembly (BJE)

Process Navigator - SAP for Me

Rework Processing - Stock-Manufactured Material (BJN)

Process Navigator - SAP for Me

Rework Processing - Work-in-Process (BJQ)

Process Navigator - SAP for Me

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Stop emailing alerts to AIF recipients
entry.content:
I think the only solution is a user-specific one. Each and every user under the recipient list needs to individually disable the alert emails from the interface monitor /AIF/IFMON.

This yellow marked button above acts as a toggle. Every time you click on it, the icon changes to one of the following:

Icon

Description

 

Never receive an email for this interface

 

 

Receive an email for the next alert

 

Receive an email for every error for this interface, regardless of alert status

Keep clicking on the icon till you get the icon for ‘No Email’, which is .

If a recipient does this, only that person will stop receiving emails. Rest will continue to receive. So, every individual under recipient list has to do this themselves.
